Utica, Wednesday P.M.
Dear Eddie,
We think now that I will not go home till Friday as we shall go to Oriskany if it is pleasant enough this afternoon. We met Annie at the Depot this morning and she wants us to go with her home. Will you tell the girls not to expect us till they see us.  Uncle is going to Boonville this afternoon and I send this with him. We rode home with him this noon and took dinner there. Have not been to Mary's yet. Uncle is coming back Saturday morning and cannot stop at Remsen. If father wants to see him he must be at the depot Sat. Morning.
Jennie.

South Headley, Nov. 20 '49
Dear Henry:
Imagine if you can, that you see me in my little room, seated by my table sighing for a letter. Three long weeks have passed since I have heard one word from any of my brothers or sisters. This is the fourth letter I have written since news from home has blessed my lonely heart. I write regularly every tuesday evening and I should not wonder if you could guess almost every time when to expect a letter from me. When we formed our society for letter writing I thought it was so arranged that we should each one get one letter every week, if it is not so, tell me in your next, so that I shall not again expect to hear when no letter is due to me. I never felt as though I had so few friends as I now feel that I have. I feel all the time as though I were in the midst of strangers. There are so many here that it is impossible to get acquainted. Every meal the tables are set for 210 persons. It seems like quite a village all in one family. Next week is thanksgiving and many of the young ladies are going home, we shall have a vacation of four days for the accomodation of such. I cannot spend it with you but if you write me some letters, I will place the likenesses that I brought with me around me and (although so many faces will be wanting) try to imagine myself really surrounded by those I love. I expect we shall have quite a pleasant day at the seminary. I have written no where but home since I have been here I hope next week to find  time to write to others. Tell Mary Thomas that then she shall hear from me.

Last week a young lady drownd herself in the mill-dam of this place. She was attending school at the Academy, she had not been very well during the day and desired to be excused from school. Her friends hearing nothing from her for three days became alarmed and after much search her body was found in the dam. It is supposed that the blood rushing to her brain deranged her and she threw herself into the water without knowing what she did.
Yesterday and today have been very rainy. I washed yesterday and my clothes are out in the rain. It is very gloomy here when it rains, every thing seems to weep. There the clock strikes 10 and I must hasten or I shall be tardy in retiring, good night.
Wednesday morn.
This morning as I was sleeping in my quiet room dreaming of absent friends I was startled by my room-mate coming in into the room and exclaiming "Oh! you will be tardy." "I expect the bell to ring every moment." I had hardly opened my eyes before I was on the floor. I am now in the middle class. I do not know whether I shall be so classed in the catalogue or not. I shall try to do my best to have it so. My time is so much taken up that I cannot stop to think, as I suppose you have thought while reading this almost senceless letter.
(We walk a mile every day when it does not rain. It seems a long way and I am pretty tired by the time I have walked a mile and back. When I get home I shall be such a walker that I shall think nothing of walking to the village and back before breakfast, or to Utica between breakfast and dinner. Has father got a new span of horses yet? If he has not, tell him I think it would be cheaper for him to send his children here to school and he would soon have no need of any. We have very beautiful sunsets here. The sun sinks in all its golden grandure behind Mt. Tom's lofty head. I must close or this will be too late for the

mail. Dont fail to write when it is your time. If I dont hear I shall think Sarah is very much worse or some of the others are sick. If you do not write soon, please to go to the village to meet me for I shall probably be there. If you have moved I wish you would send your post-office address so that I may no longer write in vain. When have you heard from Elizabeth? how is she? How does my little nephew prosper? Does mother have any help? how is father's and mother's health now? How long does Mary think of staying with Elizabeth? Is John at home now? Does Sarah sit up any? I have two extra lessons to day which make me more in haste than usual so you must excuse the shortness of this letter. I enjoy myself pretty well. My health is very good. Love to father and mother and all brothers and sisters. Dont forget you have a sister in Mt. Holyoke nor fail to write.
yours in haste Jane Ever[hole caused by seal]
P.S. Remember I am not three hundred miles from home and you need not pay more than five cents on a letter. I received one from Mary on which you had paid ten . Dont forget to direct Jane Everett. South Hadley. Mass.

They went to sleep or at least, they are faithfully courting sleep, for all is still in their roome to this time.
I should not wonder if we have rain soon. We had a little one day soon after S came and that is all with the exception two or three days when a little snow fell - the other days have been cloudless. S thought it had been cold, but after getting a report of the weather about home and Janine? I conclude it was a mistake of mine. have you had much stormy weather? How is it now? Do you keep free from colds? and is your health good? How does your essay? prosper? Yester day I received a card from Annie in which she said she had a letter from your father which you are to send to me. That reminded me that you must be looking for a letter from me!

I did not mean to leave you out in the cold when I excused you from writing so often on account of your essay?.
I have been very well and had a nice visit. Now I am preparing to go home. Expect to start for Utica Tuesday of next week. I put it off till then so that you can all write once more if you wish to ask or suggest anything before I leave. They would like to have you here in the class with Holden and then perhaps study theology with him in New York and both graduate where John is about to graduate. but I do not know what to say to them. A good many of John's books are here. Holden in that way does not have to buy many. Tuition rentals, as they call them, are only .50 a term. I will bring a Catalogue. If you have time, please send one of Johns to Holden. A. Putmann Box 209. &c
Janine? got me a R.R. ticket here for $8.50. Yesterday I inquired at the depot here and they ask $13.75 for a ticket from here to Utica. I have been thinking some of getting a ticket only to Rochester and another from

there or from Cleveland but perhaps I would not save enough to make it pay because I have a trunk. Anna is a very lively cheery child and makes us a good deal of music. Claire too is very affectionate. She is my sleep mate and also goes out walking with me and shows me the tour. Yesterday was a beautiful day and she went with to the  P. O. office and the depot and brought me back by way of Fayette and Hillsdale Its a very pretty walk We passed the residence of the late college president and the new house that is building for the present president Day before she went with me to the college museum which has quite a good collection but and arranged to make the best show. The room was cold, there being no stove in it, and so was the library in the morning when I was in it that is warmed afternoons however their stated time for having it open.

Place - Remsen? Bemsen?, Feb. 3, 1885.
My dear Nephew, Yesterday the letter came from Rev. Timothy Jones with a P..O.O.? for $37. I will inclose the letter that you may answer. Perhaps I had better keep the P.O.O.? till I see how it is made payable - then if it to you shall I sign and get it cashed or would it be be better to send it for you to make it payable to me? This is a bright quiet morning - cold and clear - I think snow shoeing must be good. Anna is much better - she took cold Saturday which culminated in a severe pain in her right lung. We were frightened and did our best to get her nicely warm in bed - gave

a can & china - Yesterday morning she had her breakfast in bed - but this morning she was up to the table - Last evening she was feeling somuch better then she had all day - So she sided some of the the little upperdrawers of the bureau by Mr. P.'s door and what do you think came to light - among all those letters & papers in the drawer this way? My Bank Book! I never expected to see it again. I am very, very thankful to our good Father. I must write to the bank. Sunday Rev. J. R. G. Floyd preached from the words "I have fought the good fight" & c. It was stormy and only a very few were present - we had communion and our J. R. G. bore the elements - through the church both sides - Mr. G. came from Floyd Saturday and put unclear at D. Price's - David brought him over in the morning to see Mr. P. and us. He told Anna that it had been a very long time since he had been preaching in our church before - In telling me about it Anna said - "I think the last time was at Cynthia's funeral" - We were very sorry so few were there. unclear and I went from here - There were none from below D.P.'s - The roads were pretty bad - unclear Griffith's funeral - there unclear

M. J.D. Griffith's Feb ?, 1885
My dear Nephew, We have been looking all the week for a letter from you. Hope we hall have it before Sunday. I inclose the P.O. order from Reb. Timothy Jones that you may make it payable to me. Please do so and ? turn it as soon as you can for I shall be easier after it has finished its journeyings. How much does your purse contain now? and how are you getting along. How much have you paid towards your board this time? Do you keep from taking cold this severe weather? We want to

know just how you are getting along in your classes, in the meetings etc. etc. Do you keep off from the ponies? Have you been to call on Mrs. Q? yet? Mrs. Wm. Thomas says you do not need Hubert? to introduce you, you will be very welcome on your own account as the grandson of those they so long knew and honored and loved. Anna and I came down here this p.m.? with George and expected to go home with him tonight. It is a bright day but rather cold. We hope A. will not get cold. She is feeling better than when I wrote before and this is the second visit for her to make this week. Yesterday I came down to the village from church meeting and went home with George about 9 p.m. It will probably be a little

later when we go home tonight. I made several calls and took tea at ?'s - Eunice Roberts is very sick. Yesterday about noon she had a very sick spell and it was 1 1/2 hours before they could bring her to. Drs. McCulough and Williams were attending her. It seems that it was something like rheumatism or neuralgia of the heart. She has had the pain all through her left ? arm and limb all the week since she was taken sick but she did not feel it about the heart till then. She is better today tho still very sick. Laura and Caroline were there yesterday and indeed most of the times since she has been sick. I am going to call there today as I take this to the office?

Night? unclear we had a box by express, a present from Mary. Wish you might share the treat with us. They have just had a letter from David. His cousin lost everything. d. is now in another store. He gets $20 a month and food and lodging at the hotel. Thursday Aug. 21, 1885. My dear Nephew, I intend going to the village in the morning to see Rev. Ed. Daires and write this to take to the mail. Anna says your morning to write home every week and when she told me she wondered whether you would be so faithful I said if we write, he will I think. So tho' I am tired I will not let this oppertunity slip. Mr. Owen, the printer is sick with typhoid fever and Mr. Daires is troubled about the setting of the of the benhadur so he asked David Price to see if I could help a little with it. I am therefore going to try if it does not rain in the morning I meant to write but it got too late. It was such a bright fair day yesterday that I was tempted and did a Daye washing. Today I ironed. Anna began a little hour cleaning today. She looked over several cups from our bedroom Clothes/meds and she said a vial from Eddie could be home a break more we would make quick work house cleaning. But we must do the real we can. I enjoy feeding and caring for the

There is still a great-deal of that snow drift left outside and in their yard. I noticed today that the little pickets? that belong on the lower edge of the roof are down. If we had only noticed it when you were home - perhaps I can fix it. We are having very pleasant weather now and it seems very nice to see the snow go so quickly and the birds in every nook and corner picking up after the snow - John Williams had just been in  - you remember when he came to collect for the Bible Society - I gave him five half dollars which you had got in exchange when you paid for your rubbers?. the other half dollar I kept and I sent it with Mr. Prichard to buy feed for our hens. It was plugged and he could not pass it so he brought it home and I took it down to David Jones. He remembered your buying the rubbers of him and his giving you several half dollars in change out of a $5 bill and he gave me unclear money instead because I said I had no other change in my purse besides what you had given me. You will please be careful again when you have any money changed to look at what you take. I told John William and requested him to look at what I had given him and he came tonight to say they are all right

Ann has been writing to May today. The letter is waiting for me to take in the morning. It seems lonely not to have George come and go and bring the mail. He is gone where he was before and I do not know when he is expected home (Anne say unclear) Jane? had a letter from Irwin? Friday. Maggie keeps about the same - not gaining - Jane means to go to see her and Clara? wrote to inquire if she can get there if she goes up on the cars?. She was in church Sunday she was very sorry not to have heard you the Sunday before but she was sick abed so that neither she nor Clara could go. I have heard several speak of how well you did. I thanked Wm. Thomas for what he had given you and said we had not expected so much. He said it was all right that you did very well indeed - John D. told Gwen? you did splendid. She told me and she said she had seen him talking with you a little before - so she asked him if he had told you how well he liked your preaching. No, he said - I did not want to spoil him - we all are too unclear to get proud! Gwen enjoyed the sermon very much but she did not feel quite sure whether you did not give Satan too high praise when you spoke of him as omniscient! She believer he knows a great deal is full of all mischief but does he know everything?

Wednesday 8-15 a.m. Another beautiful day. I am starting to the villages and will see what I can do for Rev. E. Davies tho I am not very helpful. I forgot to say anything about your ordering the spring suit. It is growing warm so you will be feeling the need of it. We think you had better do as you deem best - as to which cloth to choose - Mr. Williams will advise and help you select - we think he can tell better than we. Mary Evans charges $1 for making pants. Suppose you ask what difference it will make in the coat if you have the pants made by her. Please write before the week is out to your loving aunties unclear

Home. Apr. 30, 1885
Dear J.E.
We received your letter last evening. We are always glad to get your letter, as you know, and hope you will not forget us each week.  Have you written to your father yet since going back to college? I hope you have. We are very glad of the encouragement you get from Mr. Grove?, and sincerely hope you may do well with your declaration? — I mean what Juice? are you going to speak?? Using plain old fashioned language. My dear boy, I trust and pray that your education may be

made a blessing to you, and a great many others through you.  Have we told you that Jennie? is helping Mr. Davies with the May number of the Cenhadwr  She has been going down now every day for about a week, and coming home at night.  She says she rather enjoys the change, and I hope she will not feel any worse for it. The walking has been so bad that it has been rather hard for her to go back and forth, but it is better now — though not very dry yet. I went to the woods day before yesterday while she was gone and brought home a tiny bunch of spring beauties — the first we have had this year. I enjoyed the walk and the

flowers. Your money slips away pretty fast, doesn’t it? Have you paid anything on your board bill this term? we would like to know how that stands. I am very glad your clothes suit you so well.  Can you wear the others on wet days to save them. Will your green suit do to wear for awhile yet? We will send $5 in this to pay the tax that you speak of — please drop a card when you receive it. When Jennie first communicated with Mr. D. she asked him if he had heard anything from Mr. Greaghan? and he said he had not - she has not spoken to him of it since.  She expects they will finish setting the last form today. Much love from your loving aunts. J.E. Ashverett? over

We realize that your frequent journeys to and from Utica this term make some differences in your expenses also your new suit?, which expense will not have to be repeated very soon again.  This is P.S. No. 2.
We heard from Mary two or three days ago— she talks of coming home soon — said she might possibly come this week, but we do not expect her so soon. The Gurin? cousins are all getting well of the measles. Carroll expected to take a music lesson yesterday.  We have not heard from Maggie lately.  We have not had the maple sugar yet but will try to send you some when it comes.  We shall be anxious to hear that this reaches you safely — if you send a card you need not mention the money, only say the letter was received all right — but be sure and write immediately.  Anna

unclear, Fed 24, 1862, Dear Robbie, There is such a unclear that nobody can go with unclear letter to the office tonight and so I'm going to write a little to you. What do you say to that? Would you like a letter too? How much better it would be if I could only see you and have a nice talk with you and tell you stories? Do you like to hear stories? your unclear Robbie and unclear unclear very much. unclear is not very well now, he has been pretty sick with a cold, but he is better now. Yesterday he went with his papa and mamma to his grandpa Williams and your Aunt Anna and I went.

down to your uncle Lewis to stay with your cousin Robbie and Maggy. We had a nice time, little Maggy was very good and so was Robbie. After we had been there a while I went to the book case to look for a book to read, Robbie came and stood on a chair by me. He looked at me quite a while as I opened one book and there another and put them back - at last he offered his advice and printed to a book, which said was "the best book", It was a patent Office Report it did not seem to me as though it would be very interesting nor get quite the kind of book to read Sunday. So I laughed a little at Robbie's selection and told him that I did not think it would be right to read it Sunday. He looked very sober. He did not like to have me laugh at him. So to please him I took it down, and sure enough, it was a good book for little boys and girls. It had a

host of pictures in it, Robbie wanted to know if I thought it would be wrong to look at them Sunday. I said no, and so we took the book out into the kitchen and sat down to look at them, Maggy came and sat on my lap and Robbie sat on a chair by my side. There were pictures of cows, and sheep, squirrels, and mice and ever and ever so many kinds of birds. We had a very nice time looking at them. Among the rest we saw a king bird with a bee in its mouth. Robbie wanted to know, why it had got the bee. I told him that they were what it had to eat and that his grandpa used to have bees his papa would try to kill every king bird he could find. But what what makes the king bird eat the bees? asked Robbie again, what makes you eat bread and butter, said J. because I. Because I like it, said Robbie smiling.

and that is for me to eat. And can you tell me now why the king bird eats the bee, I asked. Yes, they like them, and that is what is for them to eat, he replied. After a while we got tired of looking at pictures and Robbie wanted to hear something about his cousins Frank and Robbie. He loves dearly to talk about you and he would be very glad to show you his pictures and every thing else pretty he has if you would only come out here. I asked him what I should say to you when I wrote to you. "O, tell them we have had four little bossys and that paper had to kill them all but one because he didn't have enough milk for them and they would die if he didn't kill them. But we have got one bossy a great deal younger than Maggy and its got great large teeth," - when we were getting supper Robbie told us where to find everything. I wonder if we should go to your house some day and your mother was not a home, whether you could tell us where to get something to eat. Do you think you could. Now, when Frank writes you  write to Aunt Jennie

Remsen, March 24, 1863
My dear Frank,
We were very glad to get your letter tho' it was so short. How is that pretty little brother of yours by this time and how is your mother? O dear, how I wish we could see you all! Or if we cannot see you I wish we could get your likenesses. Is there no chance to have them taken in Osawatomie or any other place not too far off for you to go to get them. If you will get them taken and send them to me I will send money to pay for them. I am so afraid you will get to be a great big man, and Robert and baby too, before ever

I see you. You were a little bit of a fellow when I saw you last in Utica. Your dear uncle Robert was living then and he and I went with you down to the depot to start you off.
Yesterday afternoon your uncle Lewis, aunt Jane, and three little cousins were here. Would you not have enjoyed being here with them? They are dear little children and I know you would like them. We have a little calf, two days old now, and the children were pleased enough with it. Maggie's mamma thought it was most too cold for such a little girl to go out and see it. So Maggie got the comb and parted her hair like a little boy and then she thought she might go as well as the boys. So she was bundled up and aunt Anne carried her out to see the calf. When she came in she told me the calf

did not have any horns and that it was red with a white back and that the old cow was all white.
When Anna and I were in Utica we got Maggie a set of little dishes and if you and Bobbie would come to see her she would make you a cup of tea in them. She made her Grandpa some the other day when she was there.
Tell your mother that we did get that $3.00 all safe and that we have got rennets ready to send and are only waiting to know what other things she wants sent with the rennets. I have written to her about it and I hope she has had the letter before this.
We have had a good deal of snow lately and the roads are bad now. The weather has been warm for two or three days now - Write again soon. We all send love. Your aunt Jennie.

Dear John, Will you not write and let us know particularly how Sarah and the baby are and how you all are?  When was baby born?  Frank's letter was quite too short.  I am sorry you have been so uneasy about that $3.00.  I ought to have acknowledged it sooner than I did.  I hope you have had my letter tho' now that I shall soon hear from you what things to send.  I had to give 20 cts each for rennets.  That is what farmers here get for those of deaconed calves mother think those we were getting from Uncle will be much better.  They were dried last Summer.  Last Tuesday John P. Jones (H. P. Jones' son) was buried.  He died in the hispital in Washington and yesterday father attended the funeral of another young soldier, John Hughes.  Friday last, Morris, the youngest son of John R. Griffiths was buried.  There have been a great many deaths about here the past year.  We are in usual health.  Sister Jennie

South Hadley, March 16, 1852.
Dear Sister Margaret:
I have I feel followed your example too closely and delayed this much too long Would that I could excuse myself so completely as you. I know I might plead many duties to occupy my time, but there were some little 'odds and ends' that I might have employed in answering your letter. I will therefore "Lock? the dead past bury it dead" and saying no more about it hope to be more prompt in future. You were much mistaken in supposing we had no school Christmas. The holidays were past so much as other days that they might have unclear without our knowledge, and we have entered the new year all unconcious, had not Mr. Hawk mentioned it at devotions that morning. I thought of you much that first day of the year and of Ellen. I should like to write her a letter of advice, but, Margaret, how can I? I know nothing of that tumultuous sea on which she has embarked. I cannot warn her of the shoals and quicks and nor of the rocks which be concealed by a little water, for I know not where they are. You, Margaret, have explred it a little way and are much better qualified than I

to direct her in the right course. Give my love to her and my warmest wishes that hers may be a happy voyage darkened by no storm.- It seems a long, long time since I left my home and home friends dear, and many weeks yet must be passed before I see them. How sweet the thought that in that bright world above these will be no parting, distance will be annihilated. Oh, may we all meet there.- This morning before the Sun had raised his head from "the lap of Thetis" the little birds sang sweetly. Spring has come at last, the snow is mostly gone and the grass begins to grow. The roads have hardly got settled yet, though we have had some delightful walks upon the soft turff by the roadside. I love the spring with it soft and mellow breezes, It whispers to the trees and they put forth their green leaves, the earth too hears its voice and up springs the tender grass and lovely flowers.- I hope to find Sarah pretty well when we go home. We had a letter from her last friday evening. She was still fast improving and had begun to stand up. Said she has lately received a letter from you and that Lewis wrote a "few words" in it. May we not too hope to see a "few" marks of his pen in your next? (How do you get along with your store? Do you think of going to N. York again next fall? If so I wish you could go so early that we might have your company back when we go home. My health is pretty good now. I have the rest of the sheet for Mary. When will Keossuth leave that we may have that "long letter" from Lewis? I was sorry to hear by mother's letter that your sister May is sick. Give my love to her and to all your father's? family and accept a good share yourself. Write soon your aff. sister Jane

Hudson, Dec, 1. 1855.
Mary:
Your letter should have been answered sooner had I not just sent one to Cynthia and I have been very busy. I do not get much time to write, during the week. My health is pretty good though I have quite a hard cold just now. The weather has been very unsettled since I have been here, wet and pleasant, cold and warm days, follow each other like smile and tears. This day is very pleasant, Mr. Most, has just failed in business. I do not effect this will have upon me. I hope I shall not be obliged to change my boarding place. Remsen, Apr. 16, 187?5  Dear Mary,  We received your letter yesterday morning - are very anxious about you lest you make yourself sick - wish you could get some one to help you for a little while at least.  It is very hard for us to say what we can do - we have made no arrangement.  I have written this morning to see if we can get Davis for a while - we have quite a little set on second form and hope to have the next number out early - then, if possible, Cynthia and I will try to make you that promised visit.  We would like very much to see you and know a little better how it is with you.  The roads are not yet so that we can take the horse to the village.  Cynthia is pretty feeble you know.

Of course you can keep that you got from Mrs. Jones - for a while at least - and we will try to get for you what you need to borrow.  When will you need to have it?  I wish you could get the house off your hands without any great loss as the care is too much for you, but I suppose you cannot do that now.  If Davis comes and gets along well perhaps some light will break in upon us and we will see more clearly what to do.  Mother wrote last Monday to ask Wm D. Remsen, Sep. 8, 1895.  Dear Mary,  Yours was received last evening and right glad were we to get it especially as it brought good news about little sister, we sent to the village today thinking there might be another from you.  we shall be very glad to hear again and trust we shall soon.  Mother proposes, if Cynthia thinks best, that she should take and use some of her own money now - that would make her feel more independent and maybe she would get well faster.  What is money good for if not to use - and she may never want it more than now.  She could hire some good woman to take care of her
[[vertical writing]  I have a money order from John and could send Cynthia some if needed

or she could partly hire her and you could partly do the same and perhaps the same person would be able to attend to Sis and do chamber work.  Then when Sis gets well she can earn money fast enough, and we can help her too if necessary.  John Eddie and Frank have gone to camp meeting tonight - they took unclear and the buggy and promised to come home before the prayer meeting which is held after the general service.  Mother and I are alone now as Anna and cousin Mary are in Turin.  Monday about 1/2 past 9 A.M. Lewis came up to see if cousin Mary and one of us girls would like to go with Jane to camp meeting - Anna says, yes, you go, Jennie, you are just through with

the washing and can go just as well as not.  Jane came for us with their horse and waggon and we had a charming ride - reached the grounds a little before afternoon service.  Saw many old friends Mr. & Mrs. Ames, Mary Ann? & husband and George, Mrs. Mitchel & family, cousin Marcia, and I know not how many others.  We got a seat pretty far forward so that I could hear some, but the wind made constant music with the leaves and just after the text was announced, from way up amid the tree tops a little dead branch came swiftly down lighting on the forehead of an old lady who sat a little front of us - it made quite a sensation but did not drive her from her seat - she evidently believed "that lightning never strikes twice

in the same place." Just after the close of that meeting when we were going to attend the missionary meeting, the men began to run and all went pell mell towards where the horses were tied, but before we got there we found a tree had fallen on a large tent and torn it down - no one was hurt.  Sunday night another tree was blown down near the Remsen tent it fell on and demolished a little out house  another tree broke through one of the tents, and landed in a bed between two ladies who fortunately were not injured.  Those who staid for evening service Sunday night were caught in a severe thunder storm - it was very dark and they had a pretty hard time getting home.  Frank & Maggie and I believe Robbie rode with G. Griffith folks

Remsen, Feb. 13, 1898.
My dear Sister,
Mother was greatly relieved to get your letter Monday when John Eddie came home from school. My hand is much better - you had not sent me any of that [Poor?], before but I have been taking [?] in water. Have taken nothing since Monday. Will take the Poor tonight in water.
We are sending the rest of the tubs to the village this morning. If William does not have a good offer (28 or 30 ?) he will send them to Ambler Brs by cars. We do not like to have you so much troubled with

selling the butter. Are glad you are succeeding so well with those last tubs. Mother says you are to use what you need in return for your trouble.
We shall be glad to see you whenever you can make it convenient. We are expecting Eddie and family before long. It would be nice if you could meet them here. Eddie writes that he is very well.
William drove to Utica Monday for a load of feed and came home yesterday and took me with him. I have not enjoyed anything for a long time as I did that ride and my visit at cousin's. Mary went with me over to Uncle's Monday evening. He had been quite sick with dysentery

was some better of that but he looked quite thin and feeble. They were all very cordial and we enjoyed the call. Yesterday Mary went down street with me and we got mother a cashmere double shawl and gloves - both very nice and warm we think. It snowed hard Saturday night and Sunday so that there was snow enough all the way. We went down in little less than three hours and we were about 4 1/2 coming home with the load. Everybody says we have a good horse now. I found Sarah feeling rather poorly when I got home. Today she is on the bed. They were most afraid I would stay for a visit and come in the cars, so they were extra

glad to see me.
We are glad you had such an opportunity to mingle in upper circle of New York and that you enjoyed it. Hope it will help you on a little to get introduced. I have not yet had time to look at your card, so will not return it just yet. We will take care of it. John Eddie says "The next thing we hear about Aunt Mary, she will be visiting about in her carriage, I suppose, but I wouldn't wear a train for anybody."
Write again soon as mother think so much of your letters.
All unite in love -
Your sister
J E

baths several times yesterday and today. She has tried ignatria and merenrion [?], and now she is taking arnica. She is a little better today.
Anna and I washed. Saturday it snowed, with a strong wind from the north, today also it has been very cold and stormy so that we did not put out the clothes except a few on the bars - mercury stood this morning 4' above - tonight it is about 20 degrees and cloudy - there were a great many snow birds about today.
I did not come home till Saturday evening as I suppose you learned by Fanny's card. My boil was very sore and painful - it broke Friday morning and is pretty comfortable now. My right hand is quite sore. I have done it up again. I did not have any med. to take while in Utica - since

coming home I have been taking [?]. I have not asked Lewis yet to sign that paper. It has been too cold and stormy for me to go there Edward had sent his before I got home. I hope to hear from the others soon.
Robert Griffith, [?] is to be buried tomorrow. He had been sick a long time. The funeral is to be in our church at 11 a.m. Which of Mrs. Jones' sisters died while you were home? Give much love and sympathy to her please. We know how hard it is to part with our loved ones. O, Mary, pray for me, that I may be kept very near to my Savior. I feel that I need his guidance especially now. I wish to do what is right.
Tuesday morn.- Yesterday we had a talk with William about what they ought to have for last year. There never

was any definite agreement. Mother gave them money as they asked for it and they kept the account. They have her according to that $102.85 and Jim thinks they ought to have in all $150 That will be more than what [?]sold of butter, potatoes, &c. Last spring we had to pay a good deal for hay between $30 & 40. I think we will probably have to buy some this spring if the season is late, I do not know what to do for next year - if we pay both John Eddie and Wm and Sarah - what ought we to pay them? My dear Sisters - I think it about time that we open a correspondence - once more what do you think about it? It seems an age almost since we heard from you. I fear you are sick, or something. Please send a Postal if nothing more as we are anxious to hear. - and I know you are looking for a letter from home. - We have been very busy house-cleaning, - and ave not taken time to write letters this week. We are nearly through - Caroline has been here helping us. Wm was very sick with Congestion of Lungs about twl weeks ago - Dr. Wa[?] was here three times to see him. he has had Asthma more than usual this spring. When do you think you can come home We expect John [?] Butler and wife about the last of July - and Mr. B. & Hattie sometime in August. We would be glad if you could be here a little before, and stay while they are here.
Written along the side:
We are all pretty well now. but kind of weak - will write again soon.
